35class _axis_method_wrapper:
36 """
37 Helper to generate Axes methods wrapping Axis methods.
38
39 After ::
40
41 get_foo = _axis_method_wrapper("xaxis", "get_bar")
42
43 (in the body of a class) ``get_foo`` is a method that forwards it arguments
44 to the ``get_bar`` method of the ``xaxis`` attribute, and gets its
45 signature and docstring from ``Axis.get_bar``.
46
47 The docstring of ``get_foo`` is built by replacing "this Axis" by "the
48 {attr_name}" (i.e., "the xaxis", "the yaxis") in the wrapped method's
49 dedented docstring; additional replacements can be given in *doc_sub*.
50 """
51
52 def __init__(self, attr_name, method_name, *, doc_sub=None):
53 self.attr_name = attr_name
54 self.method_name = method_name
55 # Immediately put the docstring in ``self.__doc__`` so that docstring
56 # manipulations within the class body work as expected.
57 doc = inspect.getdoc(getattr(maxis.Axis, method_name))
58 self._missing_subs = []
59 if doc:
60 doc_sub = {"this Axis": f"the {self.attr_name}", **(doc_sub or {})}
61 for k, v in doc_sub.items():
62 if k not in doc: # Delay raising error until we know qualname.
63 self._missing_subs.append(k)
64 doc = doc.replace(k, v)
65 self.__doc__ = doc
66
67 def __set_name__(self, owner, name):
68 # This is called at the end of the class body as
69 # ``self.__set_name__(cls, name_under_which_self_is_assigned)``; we
70 # rely on that to give the wrapper the correct __name__/__qualname__.
71 get_method = attrgetter(f"{self.attr_name}.{self.method_name}")
72
73 def wrapper(self, *args, **kwargs):
74 return get_method(self)(*args, **kwargs)
75
76 wrapper.__module__ = owner.__module__
77 wrapper.__name__ = name
78 wrapper.__qualname__ = f"{owner.__qualname__}.{name}"
79 wrapper.__doc__ = self.__doc__
80 # Manually copy the signature instead of using functools.wraps because
81 # displaying the Axis method source when asking for the Axes method
82 # source would be confusing.
83 wrapper.__signature__ = inspect.signature(
84 getattr(maxis.Axis, self.method_name))
85
86 if self._missing_subs:
87 raise ValueError(
88 "The definition of {} expected that the docstring of Axis.{} "
89 "contains {!r} as substrings".format(
90 wrapper.__qualname__, self.method_name,
91 ", ".join(map(repr, self._missing_subs))))
92
93 setattr(owner, name, wrapper)
94

96class _TransformedBoundsLocator:
97 """
98 Axes locator for `.Axes.inset_axes` and similarly positioned Axes.
99
100 The locator is a callable object used in `.Axes.set_aspect` to compute the
101 Axes location depending on the renderer.
102 """
103
104 def __init__(self, bounds, transform):
105 """
106 *bounds* (a ``[l, b, w, h]`` rectangle) and *transform* together
107 specify the position of the inset Axes.
108 """
109 self._bounds = bounds
110 self._transform = transform
111
112 def __call__(self, ax, renderer):
113 # Subtracting transSubfigure will typically rely on inverted(),
114 # freezing the transform; thus, this needs to be delayed until draw
115 # time as transSubfigure may otherwise change after this is evaluated.
116 return mtransforms.TransformedBbox(
117 mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(*self._bounds),
118 self._transform - ax.get_figure(root=False).transSubfigure)

121def _process_plot_format(fmt, *, ambiguous_fmt_datakey=False):
122 """
123 Convert a MATLAB style color/line style format string to a (*linestyle*,
124 *marker*, *color*) tuple.
125
126 Example format strings include:
127
128 * 'ko': black circles
129 * '.b': blue dots
130 * 'r--': red dashed lines
131 * 'C2--': the third color in the color cycle, dashed lines
132
133 The format is absolute in the sense that if a linestyle or marker is not
134 defined in *fmt*, there is no line or marker. This is expressed by
135 returning 'None' for the respective quantity.
136
137 See Also
138 --------
139 matplotlib.Line2D.lineStyles, matplotlib.colors.cnames
140 All possible styles and color format strings.
141 """
142
143 linestyle = None
144 marker = None
145 color = None
146
147 # First check whether fmt is just a colorspec, but specifically exclude the
148 # grayscale string "1" (not "1.0"), which is interpreted as the tri_down
149 # marker "1". The grayscale string "0" could be unambiguously understood
150 # as a color (black) but also excluded for consistency.
151 if fmt not in ["0", "1"]:
152 try:
153 color = mcolors.to_rgba(fmt)
154 return linestyle, marker, color
155 except ValueError:
156 pass
157
158 errfmt = ("{!r} is neither a data key nor a valid format string ({})"
159 if ambiguous_fmt_datakey else
160 "{!r} is not a valid format string ({})")
161
162 i = 0
163 while i < len(fmt):
164 c = fmt[i]
165 if fmt[i:i+2] in mlines.lineStyles: # First, the two-char styles.
166 if linestyle is not None:
167 raise ValueError(errfmt.format(fmt, "two linestyle symbols"))
168 linestyle = fmt[i:i+2]
169 i += 2
170 elif c in mlines.lineStyles:
171 if linestyle is not None:
172 raise ValueError(errfmt.format(fmt, "two linestyle symbols"))
173 linestyle = c
174 i += 1
175 elif c in mlines.lineMarkers:
176 if marker is not None:
177 raise ValueError(errfmt.format(fmt, "two marker symbols"))
178 marker = c
179 i += 1
180 elif c in mcolors.get_named_colors_mapping():
181 if color is not None:
182 raise ValueError(errfmt.format(fmt, "two color symbols"))
183 color = c
184 i += 1
185 elif c == "C":
186 cn_color = re.match(r"C\d+", fmt[i:])
187 if not cn_color:
188 raise ValueError(errfmt.format(fmt, "'C' must be followed by a number"))
189 color = mcolors.to_rgba(cn_color[0])
190 i += len(cn_color[0])
191 else:
192 raise ValueError(errfmt.format(fmt, f"unrecognized character {c!r}"))
193
194 if linestyle is None and marker is None:
195 linestyle = mpl.rcParams['lines.linestyle']
196 if linestyle is None:
197 linestyle = 'None'
198 if marker is None:
199 marker = 'None'
200
201 return linestyle, marker, color

204class _process_plot_var_args:
205 """
206 Process variable length arguments to `~.Axes.plot`, to support ::
207
208 plot(t, s)
209 plot(t1, s1, t2, s2)
210 plot(t1, s1, 'ko', t2, s2)
211 plot(t1, s1, 'ko', t2, s2, 'r--', t3, e3)
212
213 an arbitrary number of *x*, *y*, *fmt* are allowed
214 """
215
216 def __init__(self, output='Line2D'):
217 _api.check_in_list(['Line2D', 'Polygon', 'coordinates'], output=output)
218 self.output = output
219 self.set_prop_cycle(None)
220
221 def set_prop_cycle(self, cycler):
222 if cycler is None:
223 cycler = mpl.rcParams['axes.prop_cycle']
224 self._idx = 0
225 self._cycler_items = [*cycler]
226
227 def __call__(self, axes, *args, data=None, return_kwargs=False, **kwargs):
228 axes._process_unit_info(kwargs=kwargs)
229
230 for pos_only in "xy":
231 if pos_only in kwargs:
232 raise _api.kwarg_error(inspect.stack()[1].function, pos_only)
233
234 if not args:
235 return
236
237 if data is None: # Process dict views
238 args = [cbook.sanitize_sequence(a) for a in args]
239 else: # Process the 'data' kwarg.
240 replaced = [mpl._replacer(data, arg) for arg in args]
241 if len(args) == 1:
242 label_namer_idx = 0
243 elif len(args) == 2: # Can be x, y or y, c.
244 # Figure out what the second argument is.
245 # 1) If the second argument cannot be a format shorthand, the
246 # second argument is the label_namer.
247 # 2) Otherwise (it could have been a format shorthand),
248 # a) if we did perform a substitution, emit a warning, and
249 # use it as label_namer.
250 # b) otherwise, it is indeed a format shorthand; use the
251 # first argument as label_namer.
252 try:
253 _process_plot_format(args[1])
254 except ValueError: # case 1)
255 label_namer_idx = 1
256 else:
257 if replaced[1] is not args[1]: # case 2a)
258 _api.warn_external(
259 f"Second argument {args[1]!r} is ambiguous: could "
260 f"be a format string but is in 'data'; using as "
261 f"data. If it was intended as data, set the "
262 f"format string to an empty string to suppress "
263 f"this warning. If it was intended as a format "
264 f"string, explicitly pass the x-values as well. "
265 f"Alternatively, rename the entry in 'data'.",
266 RuntimeWarning)
267 label_namer_idx = 1
268 else: # case 2b)
269 label_namer_idx = 0
270 elif len(args) == 3:
271 label_namer_idx = 1
272 else:
273 raise ValueError(
274 "Using arbitrary long args with data is not supported due "
275 "to ambiguity of arguments; use multiple plotting calls "
276 "instead")
277 if kwargs.get("label") is None:
278 kwargs["label"] = mpl._label_from_arg(
279 replaced[label_namer_idx], args[label_namer_idx])
280 args = replaced
281 ambiguous_fmt_datakey = data is not None and len(args) == 2
282
283 if len(args) >= 4 and not cbook.is_scalar_or_string(
284 kwargs.get("label")):
285 raise ValueError("plot() with multiple groups of data (i.e., "
286 "pairs of x and y) does not support multiple "
287 "labels")
288
289 # Repeatedly grab (x, y) or (x, y, format) from the front of args and
290 # massage them into arguments to plot() or fill().
291
292 while args:
293 this, args = args[:2], args[2:]
294 if args and isinstance(args[0], str):
295 this += args[0],
296 args = args[1:]
297 yield from self._plot_args(
298 axes, this, kwargs, ambiguous_fmt_datakey=ambiguous_fmt_datakey,
299 return_kwargs=return_kwargs
300 )
301
302 def get_next_color(self):
303 """Return the next color in the cycle."""
304 entry = self._cycler_items[self._idx]
305 if "color" in entry:
306 self._idx = (self._idx + 1) % len(self._cycler_items) # Advance cycler.
307 return entry["color"]
308 else:
309 return "k"
310
311 def _getdefaults(self, kw, ignore=frozenset()):
312 """
313 If some keys in the property cycle (excluding those in the set
314 *ignore*) are absent or set to None in the dict *kw*, return a copy
315 of the next entry in the property cycle, excluding keys in *ignore*.
316 Otherwise, don't advance the property cycle, and return an empty dict.
317 """
318 defaults = self._cycler_items[self._idx]
319 if any(kw.get(k, None) is None for k in {*defaults} - ignore):
320 self._idx = (self._idx + 1) % len(self._cycler_items) # Advance cycler.
321 # Return a new dict to avoid exposing _cycler_items entries to mutation.
322 return {k: v for k, v in defaults.items() if k not in ignore}
323 else:
324 return {}
325
326 def _setdefaults(self, defaults, kw):
327 """
328 Add to the dict *kw* the entries in the dict *default* that are absent
329 or set to None in *kw*.
330 """
331 for k in defaults:
332 if kw.get(k, None) is None:
333 kw[k] = defaults[k]
334
335 def _make_line(self, axes, x, y, kw, kwargs):
336 kw = {**kw, **kwargs} # Don't modify the original kw.
337 self._setdefaults(self._getdefaults(kw), kw)
338 seg = mlines.Line2D(x, y, **kw)
339 return seg, kw
340
341 def _make_coordinates(self, axes, x, y, kw, kwargs):
342 kw = {**kw, **kwargs} # Don't modify the original kw.
343 self._setdefaults(self._getdefaults(kw), kw)
344 return (x, y), kw
345
346 def _make_polygon(self, axes, x, y, kw, kwargs):
347 # Polygon doesn't directly support unitized inputs.
348 x = axes.convert_xunits(x)
349 y = axes.convert_yunits(y)
350
351 kw = kw.copy() # Don't modify the original kw.
352 kwargs = kwargs.copy()
353
354 # Ignore 'marker'-related properties as they aren't Polygon
355 # properties, but they are Line2D properties, and so they are
356 # likely to appear in the default cycler construction.
357 # This is done here to the defaults dictionary as opposed to the
358 # other two dictionaries because we do want to capture when a
359 # *user* explicitly specifies a marker which should be an error.
360 # We also want to prevent advancing the cycler if there are no
361 # defaults needed after ignoring the given properties.
362 ignores = ({'marker', 'markersize', 'markeredgecolor',
363 'markerfacecolor', 'markeredgewidth'}
364 # Also ignore anything provided by *kwargs*.
365 | {k for k, v in kwargs.items() if v is not None})
366
367 # Only using the first dictionary to use as basis
368 # for getting defaults for back-compat reasons.
369 # Doing it with both seems to mess things up in
370 # various places (probably due to logic bugs elsewhere).
371 default_dict = self._getdefaults(kw, ignores)
372 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kw)
373
374 # Looks like we don't want "color" to be interpreted to
375 # mean both facecolor and edgecolor for some reason.
376 # So the "kw" dictionary is thrown out, and only its
377 # 'color' value is kept and translated as a 'facecolor'.
378 # This design should probably be revisited as it increases
379 # complexity.
380 facecolor = kw.get('color', None)
381
382 # Throw out 'color' as it is now handled as a facecolor
383 default_dict.pop('color', None)
384
385 # To get other properties set from the cycler
386 # modify the kwargs dictionary.
387 self._setdefaults(default_dict, kwargs)
388
389 seg = mpatches.Polygon(np.column_stack((x, y)),
390 facecolor=facecolor,
391 fill=kwargs.get('fill', True),
392 closed=kw['closed'])
393 seg.set(**kwargs)
394 return seg, kwargs
395
396 def _plot_args(self, axes, tup, kwargs, *,
397 return_kwargs=False, ambiguous_fmt_datakey=False):
398 """
399 Process the arguments of ``plot([x], y, [fmt], **kwargs)`` calls.
400
401 This processes a single set of ([x], y, [fmt]) parameters; i.e. for
402 ``plot(x, y, x2, y2)`` it will be called twice. Once for (x, y) and
403 once for (x2, y2).
404
405 x and y may be 2D and thus can still represent multiple datasets.
406
407 For multiple datasets, if the keyword argument *label* is a list, this
408 will unpack the list and assign the individual labels to the datasets.
409
410 Parameters
411 ----------
412 tup : tuple
413 A tuple of the positional parameters. This can be one of
414
415 - (y,)
416 - (x, y)
417 - (y, fmt)
418 - (x, y, fmt)
419
420 kwargs : dict
421 The keyword arguments passed to ``plot()``.
422
423 return_kwargs : bool
424 Whether to also return the effective keyword arguments after label
425 unpacking as well.
426
427 ambiguous_fmt_datakey : bool
428 Whether the format string in *tup* could also have been a
429 misspelled data key.
430
431 Returns
432 -------
433 result
434 If *return_kwargs* is false, a list of Artists representing the
435 dataset(s).
436 If *return_kwargs* is true, a list of (Artist, effective_kwargs)
437 representing the dataset(s). See *return_kwargs*.
438 The Artist is either `.Line2D` (if called from ``plot()``) or
439 `.Polygon` otherwise.
440 """
441 if len(tup) > 1 and isinstance(tup[-1], str):
442 # xy is tup with fmt stripped (could still be (y,) only)
443 *xy, fmt = tup
444 linestyle, marker, color = _process_plot_format(
445 fmt, ambiguous_fmt_datakey=ambiguous_fmt_datakey)
446 elif len(tup) == 3:
447 raise ValueError('third arg must be a format string')
448 else:
449 xy = tup
450 linestyle, marker, color = None, None, None
451
452 # Don't allow any None value; these would be up-converted to one
453 # element array of None which causes problems downstream.
454 if any(v is None for v in tup):
455 raise ValueError("x, y, and format string must not be None")
456
457 kw = {}
458 for prop_name, val in zip(('linestyle', 'marker', 'color'),
459 (linestyle, marker, color)):
460 if val is not None:
461 # check for conflicts between fmt and kwargs
462 if (fmt.lower() != 'none'
463 and prop_name in kwargs
464 and val != 'None'):
465 # Technically ``plot(x, y, 'o', ls='--')`` is a conflict
466 # because 'o' implicitly unsets the linestyle
467 # (linestyle='None').
468 # We'll gracefully not warn in this case because an
469 # explicit set via kwargs can be seen as intention to
470 # override an implicit unset.
471 # Note: We don't val.lower() != 'none' because val is not
472 # necessarily a string (can be a tuple for colors). This
473 # is safe, because *val* comes from _process_plot_format()
474 # which only returns 'None'.
475 _api.warn_external(
476 f"{prop_name} is redundantly defined by the "
477 f"'{prop_name}' keyword argument and the fmt string "
478 f'"{fmt}" (-> {prop_name}={val!r}). The keyword '
479 f"argument will take precedence.")
480 kw[prop_name] = val
481
482 if len(xy) == 2:
483 x = _check_1d(xy[0])
484 y = _check_1d(xy[1])
485 else:
486 x, y = index_of(xy[-1])
487
488 if axes.xaxis is not None:
489 axes.xaxis.update_units(x)
490 if axes.yaxis is not None:
491 axes.yaxis.update_units(y)
492
493 if x.shape[0] != y.shape[0]:
494 raise ValueError(f"x and y must have same first dimension, but "
495 f"have shapes {x.shape} and {y.shape}")
496 if x.ndim > 2 or y.ndim > 2:
497 raise ValueError(f"x and y can be no greater than 2D, but have "
498 f"shapes {x.shape} and {y.shape}")
499 if x.ndim == 1:
500 x = x[:, np.newaxis]
501 if y.ndim == 1:
502 y = y[:, np.newaxis]
503
504 if self.output == 'Line2D':
505 make_artist = self._make_line
506 elif self.output == 'Polygon':
507 kw['closed'] = kwargs.get('closed', True)
508 make_artist = self._make_polygon
509 elif self.output == 'coordinates':
510 make_artist = self._make_coordinates
511 else:
512 _api.check_in_list(['Line2D', 'Polygon', 'coordinates'], output=self.output)
513
514 ncx, ncy = x.shape[1], y.shape[1]
515 if ncx > 1 and ncy > 1 and ncx != ncy:
516 raise ValueError(f"x has {ncx} columns but y has {ncy} columns")
517 if ncx == 0 or ncy == 0:
518 return []
519
520 label = kwargs.get('label')
521 n_datasets = max(ncx, ncy)
522
523 if cbook.is_scalar_or_string(label):
524 labels = [label] * n_datasets
525 elif len(label) == n_datasets:
526 labels = label
527 elif n_datasets == 1:
528 msg = (f'Passing label as a length {len(label)} sequence when '
529 'plotting a single dataset is deprecated in Matplotlib 3.9 '
530 'and will error in 3.11. To keep the current behavior, '
531 'cast the sequence to string before passing.')
532 _api.warn_deprecated('3.9', message=msg)
533 labels = [label]
534 else:
535 raise ValueError(
536 f"label must be scalar or have the same length as the input "
537 f"data, but found {len(label)} for {n_datasets} datasets.")
538
539 result = (make_artist(axes, x[:, j % ncx], y[:, j % ncy], kw,
540 {**kwargs, 'label': label})
541 for j, label in enumerate(labels))
542
543 if return_kwargs:
544 return list(result)
545 else:
546 return [l[0] for l in result]

549@_api.define_aliases({"facecolor": ["fc"]})
550class _AxesBase(martist.Artist):
551 name = "rectilinear"
552
553 # axis names are the prefixes for the attributes that contain the
554 # respective axis; e.g. 'x' <-> self.xaxis, containing an XAxis.
555 # Note that PolarAxes uses these attributes as well, so that we have
556 # 'x' <-> self.xaxis, containing a ThetaAxis. In particular we do not
557 # have 'theta' in _axis_names.
558 # In practice, this is ('x', 'y') for all 2D Axes and ('x', 'y', 'z')
559 # for Axes3D.
560 _axis_names = ("x", "y")
561 _shared_axes = {name: cbook.Grouper() for name in _axis_names}
562 _twinned_axes = cbook.Grouper()
563
564 _subclass_uses_cla = False
565
566 dataLim: mtransforms.Bbox
567 """The bounding `.Bbox` enclosing all data displayed in the Axes."""
568
569 spines: mspines.Spines
570 """
571 The `.Spines` container for the Axes' spines, i.e. the lines denoting the
572 data area boundaries.
573 """
574
575 xaxis: maxis.XAxis
576 """
577 The `.XAxis` instance.
578
579 Common axis-related configuration can be achieved through high-level wrapper
580 methods on Axes; e.g. `ax.set_xticks <.Axes.set_xticks>` is a shortcut for
581 `ax.xaxis.set_ticks <.Axis.set_ticks>`. The *xaxis* attribute gives direct
582 direct access to the underlying `~.axis.Axis` if you need more control.
583
584 See also
585
586 - :ref:`Axis wrapper methods on Axes <axes-api-axis>`
587 - :doc:`Axis API </api/axis_api>`
588 """
589
590 yaxis: maxis.YAxis

592 The `.YAxis` instance.
593
594 Common axis-related configuration can be achieved through high-level wrapper
595 methods on Axes; e.g. `ax.set_yticks <.Axes.set_yticks>` is a shortcut for
596 `ax.yaxis.set_ticks <.Axis.set_ticks>`. The *yaxis* attribute gives direct
597 access to the underlying `~.axis.Axis` if you need more control.
598
599 See also
600
601 - :ref:`Axis wrapper methods on Axes <axes-api-axis>`
602 - :doc:`Axis API </api/axis_api>`
603 """

605 @property
606 def _axis_map(self):
607 """A mapping of axis names, e.g. 'x', to `Axis` instances."""
608 return {name: getattr(self, f"{name}axis")
609 for name in self._axis_names}

611 def __str__(self):
612 return "{0}({1[0]:g},{1[1]:g};{1[2]:g}x{1[3]:g})".format(
613 type(self).__name__, self._position.bounds)
614
615 def __init__(self, fig,
616 *args,
617 facecolor=None, # defaults to rc axes.facecolor
618 frameon=True,
619 sharex=None, # use Axes instance's xaxis info
620 sharey=None, # use Axes instance's yaxis info
621 label='',
622 xscale=None,
623 yscale=None,
624 box_aspect=None,
625 forward_navigation_events="auto",
626 **kwargs
627 ):
628 """
629 Build an Axes in a figure.
630
631 Parameters
632 ----------
633 fig : `~matplotlib.figure.Figure`
634 The Axes is built in the `.Figure` *fig*.
635
636 *args
637 ``*args`` can be a single ``(left, bottom, width, height)``
638 rectangle or a single `.Bbox`. This specifies the rectangle (in
639 figure coordinates) where the Axes is positioned.
640
641 ``*args`` can also consist of three numbers or a single three-digit
642 number; in the latter case, the digits are considered as
643 independent numbers. The numbers are interpreted as ``(nrows,
644 ncols, index)``: ``(nrows, ncols)`` specifies the size of an array
645 of subplots, and ``index`` is the 1-based index of the subplot
646 being created. Finally, ``*args`` can also directly be a
647 `.SubplotSpec` instance.
648
649 sharex, sharey : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes`, optional
650 The x- or y-`~.matplotlib.axis` is shared with the x- or y-axis in
651 the input `~.axes.Axes`. Note that it is not possible to unshare
652 axes.
653
654 frameon : bool, default: True
655 Whether the Axes frame is visible.
656
657 box_aspect : float, optional
658 Set a fixed aspect for the Axes box, i.e. the ratio of height to
659 width. See `~.axes.Axes.set_box_aspect` for details.
660
661 forward_navigation_events : bool or "auto", default: "auto"
662 Control whether pan/zoom events are passed through to Axes below
663 this one. "auto" is *True* for axes with an invisible patch and
664 *False* otherwise.
665
666 **kwargs
667 Other optional keyword arguments:
668
669 %(Axes:kwdoc)s
670
671 Returns
672 -------
673 `~.axes.Axes`
674 The new `~.axes.Axes` object.
675 """
676
677 super().__init__()
678 if "rect" in kwargs:
679 if args:
680 raise TypeError(
681 "'rect' cannot be used together with positional arguments")
682 rect = kwargs.pop("rect")
683 _api.check_isinstance((mtransforms.Bbox, Iterable), rect=rect)
684 args = (rect,)
685 subplotspec = None
686 if len(args) == 1 and isinstance(args[0], mtransforms.Bbox):
687 self._position = args[0].frozen()
688 elif len(args) == 1 and np.iterable(args[0]):
689 self._position = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(*args[0])
690 else:
691 self._position = self._originalPosition = mtransforms.Bbox.unit()
692 subplotspec = SubplotSpec._from_subplot_args(fig, args)
693 if self._position.width < 0 or self._position.height < 0:
694 raise ValueError('Width and height specified must be non-negative')
695 self._originalPosition = self._position.frozen()
696 self.axes = self
697 self._aspect = 'auto'
698 self._adjustable = 'box'
699 self._anchor = 'C'
700 self._stale_viewlims = dict.fromkeys(self._axis_names, False)
701 self._forward_navigation_events = forward_navigation_events
702 self._sharex = sharex
703 self._sharey = sharey
704 self.set_label(label)
705 self.set_figure(fig)
706 # The subplotspec needs to be set after the figure (so that
707 # figure-level subplotpars are taken into account), but the figure
708 # needs to be set after self._position is initialized.
709 if subplotspec:
710 self.set_subplotspec(subplotspec)
711 else:
712 self._subplotspec = None
713 self.set_box_aspect(box_aspect)
714 self._axes_locator = None # Optionally set via update(kwargs).
715
716 self._children = []
717
718 # placeholder for any colorbars added that use this Axes.
719 # (see colorbar.py):
720 self._colorbars = []
721 self.spines = mspines.Spines.from_dict(self._gen_axes_spines())
722
723 # this call may differ for non-sep axes, e.g., polar
724 self._init_axis()
725 if facecolor is None:
726 facecolor = mpl.rcParams['axes.facecolor']
727 self._facecolor = facecolor
728 self._frameon = frameon
729 self.set_axisbelow(mpl.rcParams['axes.axisbelow'])
730
731 self._rasterization_zorder = None
732 self.clear()
733
734 # funcs used to format x and y - fall back on major formatters
735 self.fmt_xdata = None
736 self.fmt_ydata = None
737
738 self.set_navigate(True)
739 self.set_navigate_mode(None)
740
741 if xscale:
742 self.set_xscale(xscale)
743 if yscale:
744 self.set_yscale(yscale)
745
746 self._internal_update(kwargs)
747
748 for name, axis in self._axis_map.items():
749 axis.callbacks._connect_picklable(
750 'units', self._unit_change_handler(name))
751
752 rcParams = mpl.rcParams
753 self.tick_params(
754 top=rcParams['xtick.top'] and rcParams['xtick.minor.top'],
755 bottom=rcParams['xtick.bottom'] and rcParams['xtick.minor.bottom'],
756 labeltop=(rcParams['xtick.labeltop'] and
757 rcParams['xtick.minor.top']),
758 labelbottom=(rcParams['xtick.labelbottom'] and
759 rcParams['xtick.minor.bottom']),
760 left=rcParams['ytick.left'] and rcParams['ytick.minor.left'],
761 right=rcParams['ytick.right'] and rcParams['ytick.minor.right'],
762 labelleft=(rcParams['ytick.labelleft'] and
763 rcParams['ytick.minor.left']),
764 labelright=(rcParams['ytick.labelright'] and
765 rcParams['ytick.minor.right']),
766 which='minor')
767
768 self.tick_params(
769 top=rcParams['xtick.top'] and rcParams['xtick.major.top'],
770 bottom=rcParams['xtick.bottom'] and rcParams['xtick.major.bottom'],
771 labeltop=(rcParams['xtick.labeltop'] and
772 rcParams['xtick.major.top']),
773 labelbottom=(rcParams['xtick.labelbottom'] and
774 rcParams['xtick.major.bottom']),
775 left=rcParams['ytick.left'] and rcParams['ytick.major.left'],
776 right=rcParams['ytick.right'] and rcParams['ytick.major.right'],
777 labelleft=(rcParams['ytick.labelleft'] and
778 rcParams['ytick.major.left']),
779 labelright=(rcParams['ytick.labelright'] and
780 rcParams['ytick.major.right']),
781 which='major')
782
783 def __init_subclass__(cls, **kwargs):
784 parent_uses_cla = super(cls, cls)._subclass_uses_cla
785 if 'cla' in cls.__dict__:
786 _api.warn_deprecated(
787 '3.6',
788 pending=True,
789 message=f'Overriding `Axes.cla` in {cls.__qualname__} is '
790 'pending deprecation in %(since)s and will be fully '
791 'deprecated in favor of `Axes.clear` in the future. '
792 'Please report '
793 f'this to the {cls.__module__!r} author.')
794 cls._subclass_uses_cla = 'cla' in cls.__dict__ or parent_uses_cla
795 super().__init_subclass__(**kwargs)
796
797 def __getstate__(self):
798 state = super().__getstate__()
799 # Prune the sharing & twinning info to only contain the current group.
800 state["_shared_axes"] = {
801 name: self._shared_axes[name].get_siblings(self)
802 for name in self._axis_names if self in self._shared_axes[name]}
803 state["_twinned_axes"] = (self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self)
804 if self in self._twinned_axes else None)
805 return state
806
807 def __setstate__(self, state):
808 # Merge the grouping info back into the global groupers.
809 shared_axes = state.pop("_shared_axes")
810 for name, shared_siblings in shared_axes.items():
811 self._shared_axes[name].join(*shared_siblings)
812 twinned_siblings = state.pop("_twinned_axes")
813 if twinned_siblings:
814 self._twinned_axes.join(*twinned_siblings)
815 self.__dict__ = state
816 self._stale = True
817
818 def __repr__(self):
819 fields = []
820 if self.get_label():
821 fields += [f"label={self.get_label()!r}"]
822 if hasattr(self, "get_title"):
823 titles = {}
824 for k in ["left", "center", "right"]:
825 title = self.get_title(loc=k)
826 if title:
827 titles[k] = title
828 if titles:
829 fields += [f"title={titles}"]
830 for name, axis in self._axis_map.items():
831 if axis.label and axis.label.get_text():
832 fields += [f"{name}label={axis.label.get_text()!r}"]
833 return f"<{self.__class__.__name__}: " + ", ".join(fields) + ">"

848 def get_window_extent(self, renderer=None):

850 Return the Axes bounding box in display space.

854 `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.get_tightbbox`.
855
856 See Also
857 --------
858 matplotlib.axes.Axes.get_tightbbox
859 matplotlib.axis.Axis.get_tightbbox
860 matplotlib.spines.Spine.get_window_extent

864 def _init_axis(self):
865 # This is moved out of __init__ because non-separable axes don't use it
866 self.xaxis = maxis.XAxis(self, clear=False)
867 self.spines.bottom.register_axis(self.xaxis)
868 self.spines.top.register_axis(self.xaxis)
869 self.yaxis = maxis.YAxis(self, clear=False)
870 self.spines.left.register_axis(self.yaxis)
871 self.spines.right.register_axis(self.yaxis)

873 def set_figure(self, fig):
874 # docstring inherited
875 super().set_figure(fig)
876
877 self.bbox = mtransforms.TransformedBbox(self._position,
878 fig.transSubfigure)
879 # these will be updated later as data is added
880 self.dataLim = mtransforms.Bbox.null()
881 self._viewLim = mtransforms.Bbox.unit()
882 self.transScale = mtransforms.TransformWrapper(
883 mtransforms.IdentityTransform())
884
885 self._set_lim_and_transforms()
886
887 def _unstale_viewLim(self):
888 # We should arrange to store this information once per share-group
889 # instead of on every axis.
890 need_scale = {
891 name: any(ax._stale_viewlims[name]
892 for ax in self._shared_axes[name].get_siblings(self))
893 for name in self._axis_names}
894 if any(need_scale.values()):
895 for name in need_scale:
896 for ax in self._shared_axes[name].get_siblings(self):
897 ax._stale_viewlims[name] = False
898 self.autoscale_view(**{f"scale{name}": scale
899 for name, scale in need_scale.items()})
900
901 @property
902 def viewLim(self):
903 """The view limits as `.Bbox` in data coordinates."""
904 self._unstale_viewLim()
905 return self._viewLim
906
907 def _request_autoscale_view(self, axis="all", tight=None):
908 """
909 Mark a single axis, or all of them, as stale wrt. autoscaling.
910
911 No computation is performed until the next autoscaling; thus, separate
912 calls to control individual axises incur negligible performance cost.
913
914 Parameters
915 ----------
916 axis : str, default: "all"
917 Either an element of ``self._axis_names``, or "all".
918 tight : bool or None, default: None
919 """
920 axis_names = _api.check_getitem(
921 {**{k: [k] for k in self._axis_names}, "all": self._axis_names},
922 axis=axis)
923 for name in axis_names:
924 self._stale_viewlims[name] = True
925 if tight is not None:
926 self._tight = tight
927
928 def _set_lim_and_transforms(self):
929 """
930 Set the *_xaxis_transform*, *_yaxis_transform*, *transScale*,
931 *transData*, *transLimits* and *transAxes* transformations.
932
933 .. note::
934
935 This method is primarily used by rectilinear projections of the
936 `~matplotlib.axes.Axes` class, and is meant to be overridden by
937 new kinds of projection Axes that need different transformations
938 and limits. (See `~matplotlib.projections.polar.PolarAxes` for an
939 example.)
940 """
941 self.transAxes = mtransforms.BboxTransformTo(self.bbox)
942
943 # Transforms the x and y axis separately by a scale factor.
944 # It is assumed that this part will have non-linear components
945 # (e.g., for a log scale).
946 self.transScale = mtransforms.TransformWrapper(
947 mtransforms.IdentityTransform())
948
949 # An affine transformation on the data, generally to limit the
950 # range of the axes
951 self.transLimits = mtransforms.BboxTransformFrom(
952 mtransforms.TransformedBbox(self._viewLim, self.transScale))
953
954 # The parentheses are important for efficiency here -- they
955 # group the last two (which are usually affines) separately
956 # from the first (which, with log-scaling can be non-affine).
957 self.transData = self.transScale + (self.transLimits + self.transAxes)
958
959 self._xaxis_transform = mtransforms.blended_transform_factory(
960 self.transData, self.transAxes)
961 self._yaxis_transform = mtransforms.blended_transform_factory(
962 self.transAxes, self.transData)
963
964 def get_xaxis_transform(self, which='grid'):
965 """
966 Get the transformation used for drawing x-axis labels, ticks
967 and gridlines. The x-direction is in data coordinates and the
968 y-direction is in axis coordinates.
969
970 .. note::
971
972 This transformation is primarily used by the
973 `~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be
974 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to
975 place axis elements in different locations.
976
977 Parameters
978 ----------
979 which : {'grid', 'tick1', 'tick2'}
980 """
981 if which == 'grid':
982 return self._xaxis_transform
983 elif which == 'tick1':
984 # for cartesian projection, this is bottom spine
985 return self.spines.bottom.get_spine_transform()
986 elif which == 'tick2':
987 # for cartesian projection, this is top spine
988 return self.spines.top.get_spine_transform()
989 else:
990 raise ValueError(f'unknown value for which: {which!r}')
991
992 def get_xaxis_text1_transform(self, pad_points):
993 """
994 Returns
995 -------
996 transform : Transform
997 The transform used for drawing x-axis labels, which will add
998 *pad_points* of padding (in points) between the axis and the label.
999 The x-direction is in data coordinates and the y-direction is in
1000 axis coordinates
1001 valign : {'center', 'top', 'bottom', 'baseline', 'center_baseline'}
1002 The text vertical alignment.
1003 halign : {'center', 'left', 'right'}
1004 The text horizontal alignment.
1005
1006 Notes
1007 -----
1008 This transformation is primarily used by the `~matplotlib.axis.Axis`
1009 class, and is meant to be overridden by new kinds of projections that
1010 may need to place axis elements in different locations.
1011 """
1012 labels_align = mpl.rcParams["xtick.alignment"]
1013 return (self.get_xaxis_transform(which='tick1') +
1014 mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(
1015 0, -1 * pad_points / 72,
1016 self.get_figure(root=False).dpi_scale_trans),
1017 "top", labels_align)
1018
1019 def get_xaxis_text2_transform(self, pad_points):
1020 """
1021 Returns
1022 -------
1023 transform : Transform
1024 The transform used for drawing secondary x-axis labels, which will
1025 add *pad_points* of padding (in points) between the axis and the
1026 label. The x-direction is in data coordinates and the y-direction
1027 is in axis coordinates
1028 valign : {'center', 'top', 'bottom', 'baseline', 'center_baseline'}
1029 The text vertical alignment.
1030 halign : {'center', 'left', 'right'}
1031 The text horizontal alignment.
1032
1033 Notes
1034 -----
1035 This transformation is primarily used by the `~matplotlib.axis.Axis`
1036 class, and is meant to be overridden by new kinds of projections that
1037 may need to place axis elements in different locations.
1038 """
1039 labels_align = mpl.rcParams["xtick.alignment"]
1040 return (self.get_xaxis_transform(which='tick2') +
1041 mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(
1042 0, pad_points / 72,
1043 self.get_figure(root=False).dpi_scale_trans),
1044 "bottom", labels_align)
1045
1046 def get_yaxis_transform(self, which='grid'):
1047 """
1048 Get the transformation used for drawing y-axis labels, ticks
1049 and gridlines. The x-direction is in axis coordinates and the
1050 y-direction is in data coordinates.
1051
1052 .. note::
1053
1054 This transformation is primarily used by the
1055 `~matplotlib.axis.Axis` class, and is meant to be
1056 overridden by new kinds of projections that may need to
1057 place axis elements in different locations.
1058
1059 Parameters
1060 ----------
1061 which : {'grid', 'tick1', 'tick2'}

1063 if which == 'grid':
1064 return self._yaxis_transform
1065 elif which == 'tick1':
1066 # for cartesian projection, this is bottom spine
1067 return self.spines.left.get_spine_transform()
1068 elif which == 'tick2':
1069 # for cartesian projection, this is top spine
1070 return self.spines.right.get_spine_transform()
1071 else:
1072 raise ValueError(f'unknown value for which: {which!r}')
1073
1074 def get_yaxis_text1_transform(self, pad_points):
1075 """

1077 -------

1079 The transform used for drawing y-axis labels, which will add
1080 *pad_points* of padding (in points) between the axis and the label.

1128 def _update_transScale(self):
1129 self.transScale.set(
1130 mtransforms.blended_transform_factory(

1133 def get_position(self, original=False):
1134 """
1135 Return the position of the Axes within the figure as a `.Bbox`.
1136
1137 Parameters
1138 ----------
1139 original : bool
1140 If ``True``, return the original position. Otherwise, return the
1141 active position. For an explanation of the positions see
1142 `.set_position`.
1143
1144 Returns
1145 -------
1146 `.Bbox`
1147
1148 """
1149 if original:
1150 return self._originalPosition.frozen()
1151 else:
1152 locator = self.get_axes_locator()
1153 if not locator:
1154 self.apply_aspect()
1155 return self._position.frozen()
1156
1157 def set_position(self, pos, which='both'):
1158 """
1159 Set the Axes position.
1160
1161 Axes have two position attributes. The 'original' position is the
1162 position allocated for the Axes. The 'active' position is the
1163 position the Axes is actually drawn at. These positions are usually
1164 the same unless a fixed aspect is set to the Axes. See
1165 `.Axes.set_aspect` for details.
1166
1167 Parameters
1168 ----------
1169 pos : [left, bottom, width, height] or `~matplotlib.transforms.Bbox`
1170 The new position of the Axes in `.Figure` coordinates.
1171
1172 which : {'both', 'active', 'original'}, default: 'both'
1173 Determines which position variables to change.
1174
1175 See Also
1176 --------
1177 matplotlib.transforms.Bbox.from_bounds
1178 matplotlib.transforms.Bbox.from_extents
1179 """
1180 self._set_position(pos, which=which)
1181 # because this is being called externally to the library we
1182 # don't let it be in the layout.
1183 self.set_in_layout(False)
1184
1185 def _set_position(self, pos, which='both'):
1186 """
1187 Private version of set_position.
1188
1189 Call this internally to get the same functionality of `set_position`,
1190 but not to take the axis out of the constrained_layout hierarchy.
1191 """
1192 if not isinstance(pos, mtransforms.BboxBase):
1193 pos = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds(*pos)
1194 for ax in self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self):
1195 if which in ('both', 'active'):
1196 ax._position.set(pos)
1197 if which in ('both', 'original'):
1198 ax._originalPosition.set(pos)
1199 self.stale = True
1200
1201 def reset_position(self):
1202 """
1203 Reset the active position to the original position.
1204
1205 This undoes changes to the active position (as defined in
1206 `.set_position`) which may have been performed to satisfy fixed-aspect
1207 constraints.
1208 """
1209 for ax in self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self):
1210 pos = ax.get_position(original=True)
1211 ax.set_position(pos, which='active')

1214 """
1215 Set the Axes locator.
1216
1217 Parameters
1218 ----------
1219 locator : Callable[[Axes, Renderer], Bbox]
1220 """
1221 self._axes_locator = locator
1222 self.stale = True
1223
1224 def get_axes_locator(self):
1225 """
1226 Return the axes_locator.
1227 """
1228 return self._axes_locator

1230 def _set_artist_props(self, a):
1231 """Set the boilerplate props for artists added to Axes."""
1232 a.set_figure(self.get_figure(root=False))
1233 if not a.is_transform_set():
1234 a.set_transform(self.transData)
1235
1236 a.axes = self
1237 if a.get_mouseover():
1238 self._mouseover_set.add(a)

1240 def _gen_axes_patch(self):
1241 """
1242 Returns
1243 -------
1244 Patch
1245 The patch used to draw the background of the Axes. It is also used
1246 as the clipping path for any data elements on the Axes.
1247
1248 In the standard Axes, this is a rectangle, but in other projections
1249 it may not be.
1250
1251 Notes
1252 -----
1253 Intended to be overridden by new projection types.
1254 """
1255 return mpatches.Rectangle((0.0, 0.0), 1.0, 1.0)
1256
1257 def _gen_axes_spines(self, locations=None, offset=0.0, units='inches'):
1258 """
1259 Returns
1260 -------
1261 dict
1262 Mapping of spine names to `.Line2D` or `.Patch` instances that are
1263 used to draw Axes spines.
1264
1265 In the standard Axes, spines are single line segments, but in other
1266 projections they may not be.
1267
1268 Notes
1269 -----
1270 Intended to be overridden by new projection types.
1271 """
1272 return {side: mspines.Spine.linear_spine(self, side)
1273 for side in ['left', 'right', 'bottom', 'top']}
1274
1275 def sharex(self, other):
1276 """
1277 Share the x-axis with *other*.
1278
1279 This is equivalent to passing ``sharex=other`` when constructing the
1280 Axes, and cannot be used if the x-axis is already being shared with
1281 another Axes. Note that it is not possible to unshare axes.
1282 """
1283 _api.check_isinstance(_AxesBase, other=other)
1284 if self._sharex is not None and other is not self._sharex:
1285 raise ValueError("x-axis is already shared")
1286 self._shared_axes["x"].join(self, other)
1287 self._sharex = other
1288 self.xaxis.major = other.xaxis.major # Ticker instances holding
1289 self.xaxis.minor = other.xaxis.minor # locator and formatter.
1290 x0, x1 = other.get_xlim()
1291 self.set_xlim(x0, x1, emit=False, auto=other.get_autoscalex_on())
1292 self.xaxis._scale = other.xaxis._scale
1293
1294 def sharey(self, other):
1295 """
1296 Share the y-axis with *other*.
1297
1298 This is equivalent to passing ``sharey=other`` when constructing the
1299 Axes, and cannot be used if the y-axis is already being shared with
1300 another Axes. Note that it is not possible to unshare axes.
1301 """
1302 _api.check_isinstance(_AxesBase, other=other)
1303 if self._sharey is not None and other is not self._sharey:
1304 raise ValueError("y-axis is already shared")
1305 self._shared_axes["y"].join(self, other)
1306 self._sharey = other
1307 self.yaxis.major = other.yaxis.major # Ticker instances holding
1308 self.yaxis.minor = other.yaxis.minor # locator and formatter.
1309 y0, y1 = other.get_ylim()
1310 self.set_ylim(y0, y1, emit=False, auto=other.get_autoscaley_on())
1311 self.yaxis._scale = other.yaxis._scale
1312
1313 def __clear(self):
1314 """Clear the Axes."""
1315 # The actual implementation of clear() as long as clear() has to be
1316 # an adapter delegating to the correct implementation.
1317 # The implementation can move back into clear() when the
1318 # deprecation on cla() subclassing expires.
1319
1320 # stash the current visibility state
1321 if hasattr(self, 'patch'):
1322 patch_visible = self.patch.get_visible()
1323 else:
1324 patch_visible = True
1325
1326 xaxis_visible = self.xaxis.get_visible()
1327 yaxis_visible = self.yaxis.get_visible()
1328
1329 for axis in self._axis_map.values():
1330 axis.clear() # Also resets the scale to linear.
1331 for spine in self.spines.values():
1332 spine._clear() # Use _clear to not clear Axis again
1333
1334 self.ignore_existing_data_limits = True
1335 self.callbacks = cbook.CallbackRegistry(
1336 signals=["xlim_changed", "ylim_changed", "zlim_changed"])
1337
1338 # update the minor locator for x and y axis based on rcParams
1339 if mpl.rcParams['xtick.minor.visible']:
1340 self.xaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator())
1341 if mpl.rcParams['ytick.minor.visible']:
1342 self.yaxis.set_minor_locator(mticker.AutoMinorLocator())
1343
1344 self._xmargin = mpl.rcParams['axes.xmargin']
1345 self._ymargin = mpl.rcParams['axes.ymargin']
1346 self._tight = None
1347 self._use_sticky_edges = True
1348
1349 self._get_lines = _process_plot_var_args()
1350 self._get_patches_for_fill = _process_plot_var_args('Polygon')
1351
1352 self._gridOn = mpl.rcParams['axes.grid']
1353 # Swap children to minimize time we spend in an invalid state
1354 old_children, self._children = self._children, []
1355 for chld in old_children:
1356 chld._remove_method = None
1357 chld._parent_figure = None
1358 chld.axes = None
1359 # Use list.clear to break the `artist._remove_method` reference cycle
1360 old_children.clear()
1361 self._mouseover_set = _OrderedSet()
1362 self.child_axes = []
1363 self._current_image = None # strictly for pyplot via _sci, _gci
1364 self._projection_init = None # strictly for pyplot.subplot
1365 self.legend_ = None
1366 self.containers = []
1367
1368 self.grid(False) # Disable grid on init to use rcParameter
1369 self.grid(self._gridOn, which=mpl.rcParams['axes.grid.which'],
1370 axis=mpl.rcParams['axes.grid.axis'])
1371 props = font_manager.FontProperties(
1372 size=mpl.rcParams['axes.titlesize'],
1373 weight=mpl.rcParams['axes.titleweight'])
1374
1375 y = mpl.rcParams['axes.titley']
1376 if y is None:
1377 y = 1.0
1378 self._autotitlepos = True
1379 else:
1380 self._autotitlepos = False
1381
1382 self.title = mtext.Text(
1383 x=0.5, y=y, text='',
1384 fontproperties=props,
1385 verticalalignment='baseline',
1386 horizontalalignment='center',
1387 )
1388 self._left_title = mtext.Text(
1389 x=0.0, y=y, text='',
1390 fontproperties=props.copy(),
1391 verticalalignment='baseline',
1392 horizontalalignment='left', )
1393 self._right_title = mtext.Text(
1394 x=1.0, y=y, text='',
1395 fontproperties=props.copy(),
1396 verticalalignment='baseline',
1397 horizontalalignment='right',
1398 )
1399 title_offset_points = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlepad']
1400 # refactor this out so it can be called in ax.set_title if
1401 # pad argument used...
1402 self._set_title_offset_trans(title_offset_points)
1403
1404 for _title in (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title):
1405 self._set_artist_props(_title)
1406
1407 # The patch draws the background of the Axes. We want this to be below
1408 # the other artists. We use the frame to draw the edges so we are
1409 # setting the edgecolor to None.
1410 self.patch = self._gen_axes_patch()
1411 self.patch.set_figure(self.get_figure(root=False))
1412 self.patch.set_facecolor(self._facecolor)
1413 self.patch.set_edgecolor('none')
1414 self.patch.set_linewidth(0)
1415 self.patch.set_transform(self.transAxes)
1416
1417 self.set_axis_on()
1418
1419 self.xaxis.set_clip_path(self.patch)
1420 self.yaxis.set_clip_path(self.patch)
1421
1422 if self._sharex is not None:
1423 self.xaxis.set_visible(xaxis_visible)
1424 self.patch.set_visible(patch_visible)
1425 if self._sharey is not None:
1426 self.yaxis.set_visible(yaxis_visible)
1427 self.patch.set_visible(patch_visible)
1428
1429 # This comes last, as the call to _set_lim may trigger an autoscale (in
1430 # case of shared axes), requiring children to be already set up.
1431 for name, axis in self._axis_map.items():
1432 share = getattr(self, f"_share{name}")
1433 if share is not None:
1434 getattr(self, f"share{name}")(share)
1435 else:
1436 # Although the scale was set to linear as part of clear,
1437 # polar requires that _set_scale is called again
1438 if self.name == "polar":
1439 axis._set_scale("linear")
1440 axis._set_lim(0, 1, auto=True)
1441 self._update_transScale()
1442
1443 self.stale = True
1444
1445 def clear(self):
1446 """Clear the Axes."""
1447 # Act as an alias, or as the superclass implementation depending on the
1448 # subclass implementation.
1449 if self._subclass_uses_cla:
1450 self.cla()
1451 else:
1452 self.__clear()
1453
1454 def cla(self):
1455 """Clear the Axes."""
1456 # Act as an alias, or as the superclass implementation depending on the
1457 # subclass implementation.
1458 if self._subclass_uses_cla:
1459 self.__clear()
1460 else:
1461 self.clear()
1462
1463 class ArtistList(Sequence):
1464 """
1465 A sublist of Axes children based on their type.
1466
1467 The type-specific children sublists were made immutable in Matplotlib
1468 3.7. In the future these artist lists may be replaced by tuples. Use
1469 as if this is a tuple already.
1470 """
1471 def __init__(self, axes, prop_name,
1472 valid_types=None, invalid_types=None):
1473 """
1474 Parameters
1475 ----------
1476 axes : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes`
1477 The Axes from which this sublist will pull the children
1478 Artists.
1479 prop_name : str
1480 The property name used to access this sublist from the Axes;
1481 used to generate deprecation warnings.
1482 valid_types : list of type, optional
1483 A list of types that determine which children will be returned
1484 by this sublist. If specified, then the Artists in the sublist
1485 must be instances of any of these types. If unspecified, then
1486 any type of Artist is valid (unless limited by
1487 *invalid_types*.)
1488 invalid_types : tuple, optional
1489 A list of types that determine which children will *not* be
1490 returned by this sublist. If specified, then Artists in the
1491 sublist will never be an instance of these types. Otherwise, no
1492 types will be excluded.
1493 """
1494 self._axes = axes
1495 self._prop_name = prop_name
1496 self._type_check = lambda artist: (
1497 (not valid_types or isinstance(artist, valid_types)) and
1498 (not invalid_types or not isinstance(artist, invalid_types))
1499 )
1500
1501 def __repr__(self):
1502 return f'<Axes.ArtistList of {len(self)} {self._prop_name}>'
1503
1504 def __len__(self):
1505 return sum(self._type_check(artist)
1506 for artist in self._axes._children)
1507
1508 def __iter__(self):
1509 for artist in list(self._axes._children):
1510 if self._type_check(artist):
1511 yield artist
1512
1513 def __getitem__(self, key):
1514 return [artist
1515 for artist in self._axes._children
1516 if self._type_check(artist)][key]
1517
1518 def __add__(self, other):
1519 if isinstance(other, (list, _AxesBase.ArtistList)):
1520 return [*self, *other]
1521 if isinstance(other, (tuple, _AxesBase.ArtistList)):
1522 return (*self, *other)
1523 return NotImplemented
1524
1525 def __radd__(self, other):
1526 if isinstance(other, list):
1527 return other + list(self)
1528 if isinstance(other, tuple):
1529 return other + tuple(self)
1530 return NotImplemented
1531
1532 @property
1533 def artists(self):
1534 return self.ArtistList(self, 'artists', invalid_types=(
1535 mcoll.Collection, mimage.AxesImage, mlines.Line2D, mpatches.Patch,
1536 mtable.Table, mtext.Text))
1537
1538 @property
1539 def collections(self):
1540 return self.ArtistList(self, 'collections',
1541 valid_types=mcoll.Collection)
1542
1543 @property
1544 def images(self):
1545 return self.ArtistList(self, 'images', valid_types=mimage.AxesImage)
1546
1547 @property
1548 def lines(self):
1549 return self.ArtistList(self, 'lines', valid_types=mlines.Line2D)
1550
1551 @property
1552 def patches(self):
1553 return self.ArtistList(self, 'patches', valid_types=mpatches.Patch)
1554
1555 @property
1556 def tables(self):
1557 return self.ArtistList(self, 'tables', valid_types=mtable.Table)
1558
1559 @property
1560 def texts(self):
1561 return self.ArtistList(self, 'texts', valid_types=mtext.Text)
1562
1563 def get_facecolor(self):
1564 """Get the facecolor of the Axes."""
1565 return self.patch.get_facecolor()
1566
1567 def set_facecolor(self, color):
1568 """
1569 Set the facecolor of the Axes.
1570
1571 Parameters
1572 ----------
1573 color : :mpltype:`color`
1574 """
1575 self._facecolor = color
1576 self.stale = True
1577 return self.patch.set_facecolor(color)
1578
1579 def _set_title_offset_trans(self, title_offset_points):
1580 """
1581 Set the offset for the title either from :rc:`axes.titlepad`
1582 or from set_title kwarg ``pad``.
1583 """
1584 self.titleOffsetTrans = mtransforms.ScaledTranslation(
1585 0.0, title_offset_points / 72,
1586 self.get_figure(root=False).dpi_scale_trans)
1587 for _title in (self.title, self._left_title, self._right_title):
1588 _title.set_transform(self.transAxes + self.titleOffsetTrans)
1589 _title.set_clip_box(None)
1590
1591 def set_prop_cycle(self, *args, **kwargs):
1592 """
1593 Set the property cycle of the Axes.
1594
1595 The property cycle controls the style properties such as color,
1596 marker and linestyle of future plot commands. The style properties
1597 of data already added to the Axes are not modified.
1598
1599 Call signatures::
1600
1601 set_prop_cycle(cycler)
1602 set_prop_cycle(label=values, label2=values2, ...)
1603 set_prop_cycle(label, values)
1604
1605 Form 1 sets given `~cycler.Cycler` object.
1606
1607 Form 2 creates a `~cycler.Cycler` which cycles over one or more
1608 properties simultaneously and set it as the property cycle of the
1609 Axes. If multiple properties are given, their value lists must have
1610 the same length. This is just a shortcut for explicitly creating a
1611 cycler and passing it to the function, i.e. it's short for
1612 ``set_prop_cycle(cycler(label=values, label2=values2, ...))``.
1613
1614 Form 3 creates a `~cycler.Cycler` for a single property and set it
1615 as the property cycle of the Axes. This form exists for compatibility
1616 with the original `cycler.cycler` interface. Its use is discouraged
1617 in favor of the kwarg form, i.e. ``set_prop_cycle(label=values)``.
1618
1619 Parameters
1620 ----------
1621 cycler : `~cycler.Cycler` or ``None``
1622 Set the given Cycler. *None* resets to the cycle defined by the
1623 current style.
1624
1625 .. ACCEPTS: `~cycler.Cycler`
1626
1627 label : str
1628 The property key. Must be a valid `.Artist` property.
1629 For example, 'color' or 'linestyle'. Aliases are allowed,
1630 such as 'c' for 'color' and 'lw' for 'linewidth'.
1631
1632 values : iterable
1633 Finite-length iterable of the property values. These values
1634 are validated and will raise a ValueError if invalid.
1635
1636 See Also
1637 --------
1638 matplotlib.rcsetup.cycler
1639 Convenience function for creating validated cyclers for properties.
1640 cycler.cycler
1641 The original function for creating unvalidated cyclers.
1642
1643 Examples
1644 --------
1645 Setting the property cycle for a single property:
1646
1647 >>> ax.set_prop_cycle(color=['red', 'green', 'blue'])
1648
1649 Setting the property cycle for simultaneously cycling over multiple
1650 properties (e.g. red circle, green plus, blue cross):
1651
1652 >>> ax.set_prop_cycle(color=['red', 'green', 'blue'],
1653 ... marker=['o', '+', 'x'])
1654
1655 """
1656 if args and kwargs:
1657 raise TypeError("Cannot supply both positional and keyword "
1658 "arguments to this method.")
1659 # Can't do `args == (None,)` as that crashes cycler.
1660 if len(args) == 1 and args[0] is None:
1661 prop_cycle = None
1662 else:
1663 prop_cycle = cycler(*args, **kwargs)
1664 self._get_lines.set_prop_cycle(prop_cycle)
1665 self._get_patches_for_fill.set_prop_cycle(prop_cycle)
1666
1667 def get_aspect(self):
1668 """
1669 Return the aspect ratio of the Axes scaling.
1670
1671 This is either "auto" or a float giving the ratio of y/x-scale.
1672 """
1673 return self._aspect
1674
1675 def set_aspect(self, aspect, adjustable=None, anchor=None, share=False):
1676 """
1677 Set the aspect ratio of the Axes scaling, i.e. y/x-scale.
1678
1679 Parameters
1680 ----------
1681 aspect : {'auto', 'equal'} or float
1682 Possible values:
1683
1684 - 'auto': fill the position rectangle with data.
1685 - 'equal': same as ``aspect=1``, i.e. same scaling for x and y.
1686 - *float*: The displayed size of 1 unit in y-data coordinates will
1687 be *aspect* times the displayed size of 1 unit in x-data
1688 coordinates; e.g. for ``aspect=2`` a square in data coordinates
1689 will be rendered with a height of twice its width.
1690
1691 adjustable : None or {'box', 'datalim'}, optional
1692 If not ``None``, this defines which parameter will be adjusted to
1693 meet the required aspect. See `.set_adjustable` for further
1694 details.
1695
1696 anchor : None or str or (float, float), optional
1697 If not ``None``, this defines where the Axes will be drawn if there
1698 is extra space due to aspect constraints. The most common way
1699 to specify the anchor are abbreviations of cardinal directions:
1700
1701 ===== =====================
1702 value description
1703 ===== =====================
1704 'C' centered
1705 'SW' lower left corner
1706 'S' middle of bottom edge
1707 'SE' lower right corner
1708 etc.
1709 ===== =====================
1710
1711 See `~.Axes.set_anchor` for further details.
1712
1713 share : bool, default: False
1714 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes.
1715
1716 See Also
1717 --------
1718 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable
1719 Set how the Axes adjusts to achieve the required aspect ratio.
1720 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor
1721 Set the position in case of extra space.
1722 """
1723 if cbook._str_equal(aspect, 'equal'):
1724 aspect = 1
1725 if not cbook._str_equal(aspect, 'auto'):
1726 aspect = float(aspect) # raise ValueError if necessary
1727 if aspect <= 0 or not np.isfinite(aspect):
1728 raise ValueError("aspect must be finite and positive ")
1729
1730 if share:
1731 axes = {sibling for name in self._axis_names
1732 for sibling in self._shared_axes[name].get_siblings(self)}
1733 else:
1734 axes = [self]
1735
1736 for ax in axes:
1737 ax._aspect = aspect
1738
1739 if adjustable is None:
1740 adjustable = self._adjustable
1741 self.set_adjustable(adjustable, share=share) # Handle sharing.
1742
1743 if anchor is not None:
1744 self.set_anchor(anchor, share=share)
1745 self.stale = True
1746
1747 def get_adjustable(self):
1748 """
1749 Return whether the Axes will adjust its physical dimension ('box') or
1750 its data limits ('datalim') to achieve the desired aspect ratio.
1751
1752 See Also
1753 --------
1754 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable
1755 Set how the Axes adjusts to achieve the required aspect ratio.
1756 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1757 For a description of aspect handling.
1758 """
1759 return self._adjustable
1760
1761 def set_adjustable(self, adjustable, share=False):
1762 """
1763 Set how the Axes adjusts to achieve the required aspect ratio.
1764
1765 Parameters
1766 ----------
1767 adjustable : {'box', 'datalim'}
1768 If 'box', change the physical dimensions of the Axes.
1769 If 'datalim', change the ``x`` or ``y`` data limits. This
1770 may ignore explicitly defined axis limits.
1771
1772 share : bool, default: False
1773 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes.
1774
1775 See Also
1776 --------
1777 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1778 For a description of aspect handling.
1779
1780 Notes
1781 -----
1782 Shared Axes (of which twinned Axes are a special case)
1783 impose restrictions on how aspect ratios can be imposed.
1784 For twinned Axes, use 'datalim'. For Axes that share both
1785 x and y, use 'box'. Otherwise, either 'datalim' or 'box'
1786 may be used. These limitations are partly a requirement
1787 to avoid over-specification, and partly a result of the
1788 particular implementation we are currently using, in
1789 which the adjustments for aspect ratios are done sequentially
1790 and independently on each Axes as it is drawn.
1791 """
1792 _api.check_in_list(["box", "datalim"], adjustable=adjustable)
1793 if share:
1794 axs = {sibling for name in self._axis_names
1795 for sibling in self._shared_axes[name].get_siblings(self)}
1796 else:
1797 axs = [self]
1798 if (adjustable == "datalim"
1799 and any(getattr(ax.get_data_ratio, "__func__", None)
1800 != _AxesBase.get_data_ratio
1801 for ax in axs)):
1802 # Limits adjustment by apply_aspect assumes that the axes' aspect
1803 # ratio can be computed from the data limits and scales.
1804 raise ValueError("Cannot set Axes adjustable to 'datalim' for "
1805 "Axes which override 'get_data_ratio'")
1806 for ax in axs:
1807 ax._adjustable = adjustable
1808 self.stale = True
1809
1810 def get_box_aspect(self):
1811 """
1812 Return the Axes box aspect, i.e. the ratio of height to width.
1813
1814 The box aspect is ``None`` (i.e. chosen depending on the available
1815 figure space) unless explicitly specified.
1816
1817 See Also
1818 --------
1819 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_box_aspect
1820 for a description of box aspect.
1821 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1822 for a description of aspect handling.
1823 """
1824 return self._box_aspect
1825
1826 def set_box_aspect(self, aspect=None):
1827 """
1828 Set the Axes box aspect, i.e. the ratio of height to width.
1829
1830 This defines the aspect of the Axes in figure space and is not to be
1831 confused with the data aspect (see `~.Axes.set_aspect`).
1832
1833 Parameters
1834 ----------
1835 aspect : float or None
1836 Changes the physical dimensions of the Axes, such that the ratio
1837 of the Axes height to the Axes width in physical units is equal to
1838 *aspect*. Defining a box aspect will change the *adjustable*
1839 property to 'datalim' (see `~.Axes.set_adjustable`).
1840
1841 *None* will disable a fixed box aspect so that height and width
1842 of the Axes are chosen independently.
1843
1844 See Also
1845 --------
1846 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1847 for a description of aspect handling.
1848 """
1849 axs = {*self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self),
1850 *self._twinned_axes.get_siblings(self)}
1851
1852 if aspect is not None:
1853 aspect = float(aspect)
1854 # when box_aspect is set to other than None`,
1855 # adjustable must be "datalim"
1856 for ax in axs:
1857 ax.set_adjustable("datalim")
1858
1859 for ax in axs:
1860 ax._box_aspect = aspect
1861 ax.stale = True
1862
1863 def get_anchor(self):
1864 """
1865 Get the anchor location.
1866
1867 See Also
1868 --------
1869 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor
1870 for a description of the anchor.
1871 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1872 for a description of aspect handling.
1873 """
1874 return self._anchor
1875
1876 def set_anchor(self, anchor, share=False):
1877 """
1878 Define the anchor location.
1879
1880 The actual drawing area (active position) of the Axes may be smaller
1881 than the Bbox (original position) when a fixed aspect is required. The
1882 anchor defines where the drawing area will be located within the
1883 available space.
1884
1885 Parameters
1886 ----------
1887 anchor : (float, float) or {'C', 'SW', 'S', 'SE', 'E', 'NE', ...}
1888 Either an (*x*, *y*) pair of relative coordinates (0 is left or
1889 bottom, 1 is right or top), 'C' (center), or a cardinal direction
1890 ('SW', southwest, is bottom left, etc.). str inputs are shorthands
1891 for (*x*, *y*) coordinates, as shown in the following diagram::
1892
1893
1894 'NW' (0.0, 1.0) 'N' (0.5, 1.0) 'NE' (1.0, 1.0)
1895
1896 'W' (0.0, 0.5) 'C' (0.5, 0.5) 'E' (1.0, 0.5)
1897
1898 'SW' (0.0, 0.0) 'S' (0.5, 0.0) 'SE' (1.0, 0.0)
1899
1900
1901 share : bool, default: False
1902 If ``True``, apply the settings to all shared Axes.
1903
1904 See Also
1905 --------
1906 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1907 for a description of aspect handling.
1908 """
1909 if not (anchor in mtransforms.Bbox.coefs or len(anchor) == 2):
1910 raise ValueError('argument must be among %s' %
1911 ', '.join(mtransforms.Bbox.coefs))
1912 if share:
1913 axes = {sibling for name in self._axis_names
1914 for sibling in self._shared_axes[name].get_siblings(self)}
1915 else:
1916 axes = [self]
1917 for ax in axes:
1918 ax._anchor = anchor
1919
1920 self.stale = True
1921
1922 def get_data_ratio(self):
1923 """
1924 Return the aspect ratio of the scaled data.
1925
1926 Notes
1927 -----
1928 This method is intended to be overridden by new projection types.
1929 """
1930 txmin, txmax = self.xaxis.get_transform().transform(self.get_xbound())
1931 tymin, tymax = self.yaxis.get_transform().transform(self.get_ybound())
1932 xsize = max(abs(txmax - txmin), 1e-30)
1933 ysize = max(abs(tymax - tymin), 1e-30)
1934 return ysize / xsize
1935
1936 def apply_aspect(self, position=None):
1937 """
1938 Adjust the Axes for a specified data aspect ratio.
1939
1940 Depending on `.get_adjustable` this will modify either the
1941 Axes box (position) or the view limits. In the former case,
1942 `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.get_anchor` will affect the position.
1943
1944 Parameters
1945 ----------
1946 position : None or .Bbox
1947
1948 .. note::
1949 This parameter exists for historic reasons and is considered
1950 internal. End users should not use it.
1951
1952 If not ``None``, this defines the position of the
1953 Axes within the figure as a Bbox. See `~.Axes.get_position`
1954 for further details.
1955
1956 Notes
1957 -----
1958 This is called automatically when each Axes is drawn. You may need
1959 to call it yourself if you need to update the Axes position and/or
1960 view limits before the Figure is drawn.
1961
1962 An alternative with a broader scope is `.Figure.draw_without_rendering`,
1963 which updates all stale components of a figure, not only the positioning /
1964 view limits of a single Axes.
1965
1966 See Also
1967 --------
1968 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_aspect
1969 For a description of aspect ratio handling.
1970 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_adjustable
1971 Set how the Axes adjusts to achieve the required aspect ratio.
1972 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_anchor
1973 Set the position in case of extra space.
1974 matplotlib.figure.Figure.draw_without_rendering
1975 Update all stale components of a figure.
1976
1977 Examples
1978 --------
1979 A typical usage example would be the following. `~.Axes.imshow` sets the
1980 aspect to 1, but adapting the Axes position and extent to reflect this is
1981 deferred until rendering for performance reasons. If you want to know the
1982 Axes size before, you need to call `.apply_aspect` to get the correct
1983 values.
1984
1985 >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1986 >>> ax.imshow(np.zeros((3, 3)))
1987 >>> ax.bbox.width, ax.bbox.height
1988 (496.0, 369.59999999999997)
1989 >>> ax.apply_aspect()
1990 >>> ax.bbox.width, ax.bbox.height
1991 (369.59999999999997, 369.59999999999997)
1992 """
1993 if position is None:
1994 position = self.get_position(original=True)
1995
1996 aspect = self.get_aspect()
1997
1998 if aspect == 'auto' and self._box_aspect is None:
1999 self._set_position(position, which='active')
2000 return
2001
2002 trans = self.get_figure(root=False).transSubfigure
2003 bb = mtransforms.Bbox.unit().transformed(trans)
2004 # this is the physical aspect of the panel (or figure):
2005 fig_aspect = bb.height / bb.width
2006
2007 if self._adjustable == 'box':
2008 if self in self._twinned_axes:
2009 raise RuntimeError("Adjustable 'box' is not allowed in a "
2010 "twinned Axes; use 'datalim' instead")
2011 box_aspect = aspect * self.get_data_ratio()
2012 pb = position.frozen()
2013 pb1 = pb.shrunk_to_aspect(box_aspect, pb, fig_aspect)
2014 self._set_position(pb1.anchored(self.get_anchor(), pb), 'active')
2015 return
2016
2017 # The following is only seen if self._adjustable == 'datalim'
2018 if self._box_aspect is not None:
2019 pb = position.frozen()
2020 pb1 = pb.shrunk_to_aspect(self._box_aspect, pb, fig_aspect)
2021 self._set_position(pb1.anchored(self.get_anchor(), pb), 'active')
2022 if aspect == "auto":
2023 return
2024
2025 # reset active to original in case it had been changed by prior use
2026 # of 'box'
2027 if self._box_aspect is None:
2028 self._set_position(position, which='active')
2029 else:
2030 position = pb1.anchored(self.get_anchor(), pb)
2031
2032 x_trf = self.xaxis.get_transform()
2033 y_trf = self.yaxis.get_transform()
2034 xmin, xmax = x_trf.transform(self.get_xbound())
2035 ymin, ymax = y_trf.transform(self.get_ybound())
2036 xsize = max(abs(xmax - xmin), 1e-30)
2037 ysize = max(abs(ymax - ymin), 1e-30)
2038
2039 box_aspect = fig_aspect * (position.height / position.width)
2040 data_ratio = box_aspect / aspect
2041
2042 y_expander = data_ratio * xsize / ysize - 1
2043 # If y_expander > 0, the dy/dx viewLim ratio needs to increase
2044 if abs(y_expander) < 0.005:
2045 return
2046
2047 dL = self.dataLim
2048 x0, x1 = x_trf.transform(dL.intervalx)
2049 y0, y1 = y_trf.transform(dL.intervaly)
2050 xr = 1.05 * (x1 - x0)
2051 yr = 1.05 * (y1 - y0)
2052
2053 xmarg = xsize - xr
2054 ymarg = ysize - yr
2055 Ysize = data_ratio * xsize
2056 Xsize = ysize / data_ratio
2057 Xmarg = Xsize - xr
2058 Ymarg = Ysize - yr
2059 # Setting these targets to, e.g., 0.05*xr does not seem to help.
2060 xm = 0
2061 ym = 0
2062
2063 shared_x = self in self._shared_axes["x"]
2064 shared_y = self in self._shared_axes["y"]
2065
2066 if shared_x and shared_y:
2067 raise RuntimeError("set_aspect(..., adjustable='datalim') or "
2068 "axis('equal') are not allowed when both axes "
2069 "are shared. Try set_aspect(..., "
2070 "adjustable='box').")
2071
2072 # If y is shared, then we are only allowed to change x, etc.
2073 if shared_y:
2074 adjust_y = False
2075 else:
2076 if xmarg > xm and ymarg > ym:
2077 adjy = ((Ymarg > 0 and y_expander < 0) or
2078 (Xmarg < 0 and y_expander > 0))
2079 else:
2080 adjy = y_expander > 0
2081 adjust_y = shared_x or adjy # (Ymarg > xmarg)
2082
2083 if adjust_y:
2084 yc = 0.5 * (ymin + ymax)
2085 y0 = yc - Ysize / 2.0
2086 y1 = yc + Ysize / 2.0
2087 if not self.get_autoscaley_on():
2088 _log.warning("Ignoring fixed y limits to fulfill fixed data aspect "
2089 "with adjustable data limits.")
2090 self.set_ybound(y_trf.inverted().transform([y0, y1]))
2091 else:
2092 xc = 0.5 * (xmin + xmax)
2093 x0 = xc - Xsize / 2.0
2094 x1 = xc + Xsize / 2.0
2095 if not self.get_autoscalex_on():
2096 _log.warning("Ignoring fixed x limits to fulfill fixed data aspect "
2097 "with adjustable data limits.")
2098 self.set_xbound(x_trf.inverted().transform([x0, x1]))
2099
2100 def axis(self, arg=None, /, *, emit=True, **kwargs):
2101 """
2102 Convenience method to get or set some axis properties.
2103
2104 Call signatures::
2105
2106 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis()
2107 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis([xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax])
2108 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(option)
2109 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = axis(**kwargs)
2110
2111 Parameters
2112 ----------
2113 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax : float, optional
2114 The axis limits to be set. This can also be achieved using ::
2115
2116 ax.set(xlim=(xmin, xmax), ylim=(ymin, ymax))
2117
2118 option : bool or str
2119 If a bool, turns axis lines and labels on or off. If a string,
2120 possible values are:
2121
2122 ================ ===========================================================
2123 Value Description
2124 ================ ===========================================================
2125 'off' or `False` Hide all axis decorations, i.e. axis labels, spines,
2126 tick marks, tick labels, and grid lines.
2127 This is the same as `~.Axes.set_axis_off()`.
2128 'on' or `True` Do not hide all axis decorations, i.e. axis labels, spines,
2129 tick marks, tick labels, and grid lines.
2130 This is the same as `~.Axes.set_axis_on()`.
2131 'equal' Set equal scaling (i.e., make circles circular) by
2132 changing the axis limits. This is the same as
2133 ``ax.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='datalim')``.
2134 Explicit data limits may not be respected in this case.
2135 'scaled' Set equal scaling (i.e., make circles circular) by
2136 changing dimensions of the plot box. This is the same as
2137 ``ax.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C')``.
2138 Additionally, further autoscaling will be disabled.
2139 'tight' Set limits just large enough to show all data, then
2140 disable further autoscaling.
2141 'auto' Automatic scaling (fill plot box with data).
2142 'image' 'scaled' with axis limits equal to data limits.
2143 'square' Square plot; similar to 'scaled', but initially forcing
2144 ``xmax-xmin == ymax-ymin``.
2145 ================ ===========================================================
2146
2147 emit : bool, default: True
2148 Whether observers are notified of the axis limit change.
2149 This option is passed on to `~.Axes.set_xlim` and
2150 `~.Axes.set_ylim`.
2151
2152 Returns
2153 -------
2154 xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax : float
2155 The axis limits.
2156
2157 See Also
2158 --------
2159 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_xlim
2160 matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_ylim
2161
2162 Notes
2163 -----
2164 For 3D Axes, this method additionally takes *zmin*, *zmax* as
2165 parameters and likewise returns them.
2166 """
2167 if isinstance(arg, (str, bool)):
2168 if arg is True:
2169 arg = 'on'
2170 if arg is False:
2171 arg = 'off'
2172 arg = arg.lower()
2173 if arg == 'on':
2174 self.set_axis_on()
2175 elif arg == 'off':
2176 self.set_axis_off()
2177 elif arg in [
2178 'equal', 'tight', 'scaled', 'auto', 'image', 'square']:
2179 self.set_autoscale_on(True)
2180 self.set_aspect('auto')
2181 self.autoscale_view(tight=False)
2182 if arg == 'equal':
2183 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='datalim')
2184 elif arg == 'scaled':
2185 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C')
2186 self.set_autoscale_on(False) # Req. by Mark Bakker
2187 elif arg == 'tight':
2188 self.autoscale_view(tight=True)
2189 self.set_autoscale_on(False)
2190 elif arg == 'image':
2191 self.autoscale_view(tight=True)
2192 self.set_autoscale_on(False)
2193 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C')
2194 elif arg == 'square':
2195 self.set_aspect('equal', adjustable='box', anchor='C')
2196 self.set_autoscale_on(False)
2197 xlim = self.get_xlim()
2198 ylim = self.get_ylim()
2199 edge_size = max(np.diff(xlim), np.diff(ylim))[0]
2200 self.set_xlim([xlim[0], xlim[0] + edge_size],
2201 emit=emit, auto=False)
2202 self.set_ylim([ylim[0], ylim[0] + edge_size],
2203 emit=emit, auto=False)
2204 else:
2205 raise ValueError(f"Unrecognized string {arg!r} to axis; "
2206 "try 'on' or 'off'")
2207 else:
2208 if arg is not None:
2209 if len(arg) != 2*len(self._axis_names):
2210 raise TypeError(
2211 "The first argument to axis() must be an iterable of the form "
2212 "[{}]".format(", ".join(
2213 f"{name}min, {name}max" for name in self._axis_names)))
2214 limits = {
2215 name: arg[2*i:2*(i+1)]
2216 for i, name in enumerate(self._axis_names)
2217 }
2218 else:
2219 limits = {}
2220 for name in self._axis_names:
2221 ax_min = kwargs.pop(f'{name}min', None)
2222 ax_max = kwargs.pop(f'{name}max', None)
2223 limits[name] = (ax_min, ax_max)
2224 for name, (ax_min, ax_max) in limits.items():
2225 ax_auto = (None # Keep autoscale state as is.
2226 if ax_min is None and ax_max is None
2227 else False) # Turn off autoscale.
2228 set_ax_lim = getattr(self, f'set_{name}lim')
2229 set_ax_lim(ax_min, ax_max, emit=emit, auto=ax_auto)
2230 if kwargs:
2231 raise _api.kwarg_error("axis", kwargs)
2232 lims = ()
2233 for name in self._axis_names:
2234 get_ax_lim = getattr(self, f'get_{name}lim')
2235 lims += get_ax_lim()
2236 return lims

2308 def add_artist(self, a):
2309 """
2310 Add an `.Artist` to the Axes; return the artist.
2311
2312 Use `add_artist` only for artists for which there is no dedicated
2313 "add" method; and if necessary, use a method such as `update_datalim`
2314 to manually update the `~.Axes.dataLim` if the artist is to be included
2315 in autoscaling.
2316
2317 If no ``transform`` has been specified when creating the artist (e.g.
2318 ``artist.get_transform() == None``) then the transform is set to
2319 ``ax.transData``.
2320 """
2321 a.axes = self
2322 self._children.append(a)
2323 a._remove_method = self._children.remove
2324 self._set_artist_props(a)
2325 if a.get_clip_path() is None:
2326 a.set_clip_path(self.patch)
2327 self.stale = True
2328 return a

2330 def add_child_axes(self, ax):
2331 """
2332 Add an `.Axes` to the Axes' children; return the child Axes.
2333
2334 This is the lowlevel version. See `.axes.Axes.inset_axes`.
2335 """
2336
2337 # normally Axes have themselves as the Axes, but these need to have
2338 # their parent...
2339 # Need to bypass the getter...
2340 ax._axes = self
2341 ax.stale_callback = martist._stale_axes_callback
2342
2343 self.child_axes.append(ax)
2344 ax._remove_method = functools.partial(
2345 self.get_figure(root=False)._remove_axes, owners=[self.child_axes])
2346 self.stale = True

2349 def add_collection(self, collection, autolim=True):
2350 """
2351 Add a `.Collection` to the Axes; return the collection.
2352 """
2353 _api.check_isinstance(mcoll.Collection, collection=collection)
2354 if not collection.get_label():
2355 collection.set_label(f'_child{len(self._children)}')
2356 self._children.append(collection)
2357 collection._remove_method = self._children.remove
2358 self._set_artist_props(collection)
2359
2360 if collection.get_clip_path() is None:
2361 collection.set_clip_path(self.patch)
2362
2363 if autolim:
2364 # Make sure viewLim is not stale (mostly to match
2365 # pre-lazy-autoscale behavior, which is not really better).
2366 self._unstale_viewLim()
2367 datalim = collection.get_datalim(self.transData)
2368 points = datalim.get_points()
2369 if not np.isinf(datalim.minpos).all():
2370 # By definition, if minpos (minimum positive value) is set
2371 # (i.e., non-inf), then min(points) <= minpos <= max(points),
2372 # and minpos would be superfluous. However, we add minpos to
2373 # the call so that self.dataLim will update its own minpos.
2374 # This ensures that log scales see the correct minimum.
2375 points = np.concatenate([points, [datalim.minpos]])
2376 self.update_datalim(points)
2377
2378 self.stale = True
2379 return collection
